notes.title: Official Syllabus & Recent Past Papers (Must-Have)
notes.content: Use the FPSC syllabus to anchor prep and map each author/work to marks. Practice with recent descriptive papers to gauge weightage (poetry, drama, novel, essays, theory).
keyTakeaways: Paper spans Essays, Short Stories, Poetry, Drama, Novel, Literary Theory/Criticism.
Start from FPSC PDFs; then drill recurring authors and theories.
Attempt timed papers from 2021–2024 to calibrate depth/speed.

notes.title: Wordsworth's Nature & 'Tintern Abbey'
notes.content: Core Romantic theme of memory, nature's moral education, and the shift from youthful ecstasy to mature reflection. Frequently examined for close reading and thematic essays.
keyTakeaways: Memory mediates nature → mind; adulthood compensates with 'philosophic mind'.
Link to Romantic aesthetics: sublime, imagination, time/change.
Use line-referenced analysis for introduction/body/close-reading.

notes.title: Keats' Odes: Sensuousness, Hellenism, Pleasure–Pain
notes.content: Expect questions on sensuous imagery, negative capability, and classical form. Compare 'Nightingale', 'Grecian Urn', 'Melancholy', 'Autumn'.
keyTakeaways: Keats fuses sensory richness with philosophical melancholy.
Pleasure–pain co-presence is a recurring argumentative thread.
Quote economically; analyze form (ode structure) + imagery.

resources.title: Hyperbolit — What is an Ode? (Keats focus)

notes.title: Dickens' 'Hard Times': Utilitarianism & Industrial Modernity
notes.content: CSS loves Dickens as social critic. 'Hard Times' targets facts-only pedagogy, mechanized labor, and moral arithmetic of utility.
keyTakeaways: Contrast 'facts' vs. imagination/humanity (Gradgrind system).
Map industrial Coketown to social critique (education/family).
Use Utilitarianism definitions to sharpen argument.

resources.title: Scholarly PDF — Critique of Utilitarianism in 'Hard Times'
Context article on Utilitarianism in Dickens

notes.title: George Eliot: Psychological Realism ('The Mill on the Floss')
notes.content: Eliot's narrative voice, interiority, and ethical realism make her a CSS favorite. Expect questions on Maggie Tulliver, Bildung, and gender constraints.
keyTakeaways: 'Sympathy' and moral choice underpin Eliot's realism.
Track setting (St. Ogg's) and social pressures shaping character arcs.
Use close-reading of narrator intrusions to evidence 'psychological realism'.

resources.title: SparkNotes — The Mill on the Floss (analysis)

notes.title: Shaw's 'Pygmalion': Social Satire, Class & Language
notes.content: Frequent essay prompts on class mobility, phonetics, and gender politics. Situate Eliza's transformation against Edwardian class codes.
keyTakeaways: Language functions as social currency and control.
Satire exposes arbitrariness of 'respectability'.
Compare with 'art for art's sake' vs. Shaw's social purpose.

resources.title: Journal piece — Pygmalion as social commentary

notes.title: Shakespeare's 'Hamlet': Delay, Revenge & Tragic Form
notes.content: Perennial CSS topic: motives for delay, problem of action vs. thought, role of Gertrude/Ophelia, and revenge-tragedy conventions.
keyTakeaways: Frame delay via ethics, epistemic doubt, and dramaturgy.
Use revenge-tragedy template (ghost–villain–avenger) as scaffold.
Integrate soliloquy analysis ('To be…') with text evidence.

notes.title: Beckett's 'Waiting for Godot': Absurdism & Existential Themes
notes.content: Expect theory-linked answers (Absurdism, existentialism), minimalism, cyclical time, and language breakdown.
keyTakeaways: Form embodies meaning: repetition, stasis, comic-tragic tone.
Map Camusian absurd vs. religious/meaning horizons.
Close-read stage directions and pauses for argument support.

notes.title: Eliot's 'The Waste Land': Fragmentation, Allusion & Post-WWI Disillusion
notes.content: CSS frequently probes structure (5 parts), voices, mythic method, and spiritual desiccation vs. renewal.
keyTakeaways: Pair text with author's notes and modernist context.
Use select allusions (Upanishads; Thames; Tiresias) judiciously.
Relate to post-war malaise + private biography (with restraint).

resources.title: Open Yale Courses — Modern Poetry (Eliot lectures)

notes.title: Non-Fiction Prose: Orwell's 'Politics and the English Language'
notes.content: Regular essay and MCQ focus: Orwell's six rules, link between thought and language, political obfuscation.
keyTakeaways: Style is ethical: clarity battles euphemism and doublespeak.
Illustrate rules with your own re-writes in answers.
Contextualize 1946 Horizon publication; ongoing relevance.

notes.title: Literary Theory Toolkit for CSS Answers
notes.content: Use theory as lens, not name-dropping. Common CSS frameworks: Formalism/New Criticism, Feminist, Marxist, Post-colonial, Reader-Response, Structuralism/Deconstruction.
keyTakeaways: State the lens in one line; apply to a short passage/example.
Balance authorial context with text-immanent analysis.
Avoid over-theorizing—keep argument serviceable to the text.

resources.title: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy — Aesthetic Formalism

notes.title: Primary Texts (Authoritative, Free) for Quotations
notes.content: Keep a local corpus for quick quotation with line numbers/sections. Use reputable public-domain sources.
keyTakeaways: Quote sparingly but precisely (act/scene; stanza/line).
Build a personal 'evidence bank' for fast recall in essays.
Cross-check any web PDF with recognized editions.
